cards.name: Phyrexian Plaguelord
cards.text:
{T}, Sacrifice Phyrexian Plaguelord: Target creature gets -4/-4 until end of turn.
Sacrifice a creature: Target creature gets -1/-1 until end of turn.

cards.name: Hatred
cards.text:
As an additional cost to cast this spell, pay X life.
Target creature gets +X/+0 until end of turn.
cards.flavorText:
"I will flay the skin from your flesh and the flesh from your bones and scrape your bones dry. And still you will not have suffered enough."
—Greven *il*-Vec, to Gerrard

rulings.text: The life payment is part of the cost to cast Hatred, so it is lost if this spell is countered.

cards.name: Phyrexian Negator
cards.text:
Trample
Whenever Phyrexian Negator is dealt damage, sacrifice that many permanents.
cards.flavorText: They exist to cease.

rulings.text: Sacrificing this card does not prevent you from having to make the other sacrifices.

cards.name: Phyrexian Negator
cards.text:
Trample
Whenever Phyrexian Negator is dealt damage, sacrifice that many permanents.
cards.flavorText: They exist to cease.

rulings.text: Sacrificing this card does not prevent you from having to make the other sacrifices.

cards.name: Rapid Decay
cards.text:
Exile up to three target cards from a single graveyard.
Cycling {2} ({2}, Discard this card: Draw a card.)
cards.flavorText: The grave robbers arrived the day after the burial. They were a day too late.

rulings.text: You pick the cards during announcement. If any are not there on resolution, any others that are there are still affected.

Cycling is an activated ability. Effects that interact with activated abilities (such as Stifle or Rings of Brighthearth) will interact with cycling. Effects that interact with spells (such as Remove Soul or Faerie Tauntings) will not.

Haste

cards.name: Covetous Dragon
cards.text:
Flying
When you control no artifacts, sacrifice Covetous Dragon.
cards.flavorText: Gatha survived as long as he did by giving all Keld's predators exactly what they wanted.

rulings.text: The ability will trigger if you don’t control an artifact, even for a brief moment during the resolution of another spell or ability.
The ability only checks if you control no artifacts at the time it triggers. It does not check again on resolution. So gaining control of an artifact before then will not save the Dragon.

cards.name: Flowstone Flood
cards.text:
Buyback—Pay 3 life, Discard a card at random. (You may pay 3 life and discard a card at random in addition to any other costs as you cast this spell. If you do, put this card into your hand as it resolves.)
Destroy target land.

rulings.text: You can’t pay the Buyback cost unless you have at least one card in your hand to discard.

cards.name: Rack and Ruin
cards.text: Destroy two target artifacts.
cards.flavorText:

rulings.text: Must target two different artifacts.

cards.name: Shock

cards.text: Whenever a player casts a spell, Spellshock deals 2 damage to that player.

cards.name: Rancor
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +2/+0 and has trample.
When Rancor is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, return Rancor to its owner's hand.

rulings.text: If the creature this Aura would enchant is an illegal target by the time Rancor tries to resolve, the Aura spell doesn't resolve. It won't enter the battlefield, so it won't be put into a graveyard from the battlefield and its ability won't trigger.

cards.name: Corpse Dance
cards.text:
Buyback {2} (You may pay an additional {2} as you cast this spell. If you do, put this card into your hand as it resolves.)
Return the top creature card of your graveyard to the battlefield. That creature gains haste until end of turn. Exile it at the beginning of the next end step.

rulings.text: Corpse Dance only exiles the card if the card is still on the battlefield at the beginning of the end step.
The effect only grants Haste until the end of the current turn. If the creature somehow manages to stick around until a later turn, it will no longer have Haste.

You pick the 0, 1, 2, or 3 target cards on announcement.

rulings.text: Only destroys artifacts and creatures with exactly the specified cost. It does not mean “less than or equal to”.
Putting on a counter is optional. If you forget, you can’t go back later even if it is something you usually do.

cards.name: Ghitu Encampment
cards.text:
Ghitu Encampment enters the battlefield tapped.
{T}: Add {R}.
{1}{R}: Ghitu Encampment becomes a 2/1 red Warrior creature with first strike until end of turn. It's still a land. (It deals combat damage before creatures without first strike.)

rulings.text: A noncreature permanent that turns into a creature can attack, and its {T} abilities can be activated, only if its controller has continuously controlled that permanent since the beginning of their most recent turn. It doesn’t matter how long the permanent has been a creature.

Activating the ability that turns it into a creature while it’s already a creature will override any effects that set its power and/or toughness to a specific number. However, any effect that raises or lowers power and/or toughness (such as the effect created by Giant Growth, Glorious Anthem, or a +1/+1 counter) will continue to apply.

cards.name: Spawning Pool
cards.text:
Spawning Pool enters the battlefield tapped.
{T}: Add {B}.
{1}{B}: Spawning Pool becomes a 1/1 black Skeleton creature with "{B}: Regenerate this creature" until end of turn. It's still a land. (If it regenerates, the next time it would be destroyed this turn, it isn't. Instead tap it, remove all damage from it, and remove it from combat.)

rulings.text: A noncreature permanent that turns into a creature can attack, and its {T} abilities can be activated, only if its controller has continuously controlled that permanent since the beginning of their most recent turn. It doesn’t matter how long the permanent has been a creature.

Activating the ability that turns it into a creature while it’s already a creature will override any effects that set its power and/or toughness to a specific number. However, any effect that raises or lowers power and/or toughness (such as the effect created by Giant Growth, Glorious Anthem, or a +1/+1 counter) will continue to apply.

cards.flavorText:
"I write upon clean white parchment with a sharp quill and the blood of my students, divining their secrets."
—Shauku, Endbringer

rulings.text: The “shuffle and put the card on top” is a single action. If an effect causes the top card of the library to be face up, the second card down is not revealed.

cards.name: Boil
cards.text: Destroy all Islands.
cards.flavorText:
"The fishers will throw out their nets and draw them back filled with dust."
—Oracle *en*-Vec

cards.name: Yawgmoth's Will
cards.text:
Until end of turn, you may play lands and cast spells from your graveyard.
If a card would be put into your graveyard from anywhere this turn, exile that card instead.

rulings.text: If you cast a Buyback spell, then there will be two effects trying to replace where the card goes. You get to choose if the Buyback returns the card to your hand or the card gets exiled.

If an effect asks you to discard a card, you can’t “discard” something that is in your graveyard. Those cards are not in your hand. Thus, Cycling abilities of cards in the graveyard can’t be activated.
The second ability creates a replacement effect. It applies to both costs and effects.
If you play a card using Yawgmoth’s Will and something triggers only when “cast from your hand”, that something will not trigger. Such things trigger based on where the card came from.
To “play a card” is to either cast a spell or to put a land onto the battlefield using the main phase special action.
It will exile itself since it goes to the graveyard after its effect starts.
You cannot Suspend a card from your graveyard, only your hand.

cards.name: Earthquake
cards.text: Earthquake deals X damage to each creature without flying and each player.

rulings.text: Whether or not a creature is without flying is only checked on resolution.

cards.name: Arc Lightning
cards.text: Arc Lightning deals 3 damage divided as you choose among one, two, or three targets.
cards.flavorText: Rainclouds don't last long in Shiv, but that doesn't stop the lightning.

rulings.text: You choose how many targets Arc Lightning has and how the damage is divided as you cast the spell. Each target must receive at least 1 damage.

If some of the creatures are illegal targets as Arc Lightning tries to resolve, the original division of damage still applies but no damage is dealt to the illegal targets. If all targets are illegal, Arc Lightning doesn’t resolve.

cards.name: Cursed Scroll
cards.text: {3}, {T}: Choose a card name, then reveal a card at random from your hand. If that card has the chosen name, Cursed Scroll deals 2 damage to any target.

cards.name: Temporal Aperture
cards.text: {5}, {T}: Shuffle your library, then reveal the top card. Until end of turn, for as long as that card remains on top of your library, play with the top card of your library revealed and you may play that card without paying its mana cost. (If it has X in its mana cost, X is 0.)

rulings.text: While you do not have to pay the mana cost, you do have to pay any other costs described in the text that are paid when playing the card. If the cost in the card text is optional, such as with Buyback, you can optionally pay that cost.
If your library is shuffled or that card otherwise leaves the top of your library, the effect ends.
The card is removed from the top of the library when you play it, just like a card is removed from your hand when you play it.

tokens.name: Matt Linde Bio
tokens.text: Semifinalist Matt Linde is no stranger to high-level Magic® competition. The 18-year-old Maryland native was the 1998 U.S. National Champion. Linde played a very fast mono-green "Stompy" deck with 26 creatures—24 of which cost two mana or less to play. Supplementing this furious creature assault were four Rancors and four Giant Growths. Though the deck was designed to win by turn five, it did feature four Cursed Scrolls in case the game dragged on.

tokens.name: Mark Le Pine Bio
tokens.text: Though only 17 years old, New Hampshire—native Mark Le Pine is a Pro Tour veteran. He has been with the Pro Tour since Atlanta '96 and has made the Top 8 three times (Mainz '97, Rome '98, and Worlds '99). Le Pine played an aggressive red deck called "Sped Red." With his deck he applied pressure early with 11 fast creatures, then he'd shift into land-destruction mode with Wasteland, Stone Rain, Pillage, and Avalanche Riders. For the late game Le Pine used Cursed Scroll and Hammer of Bogardan to finish off his mana-crippled opponent.

tokens.name: Kai Budde Bio
tokens.text: Known as the "King of the Grand Prix," Kai Budde earned an unprecedented three Grand Prix titles in 1999. Though he went only 4—2 during the Swiss portion of the World Championships, he cruised through the Final 8 to become the 1999 World Champion. The 19-year-old Köln, Germany native played a red-artifact deck that contained more than 30 artifacts. He used those artifacts to quickly generate huge amounts of mana, with which he could play a big creature like Masticore or Covetous Dragon. He would then finish off his opponent with a well-timed Wildfire.

tokens.name: Jakub Šlemr Bio (1999)
tokens.text: 1997 World Champion Jakub Šlemr came within two matches of becoming the first person to repeat as World Champion. The 22-year-old Prague native earned a flawless 6—0 resord during the Standard portion of the Swiss rounds. Šlemr, along with fellow teammate and quarterfinalist Gary Wise, played a mono-black deck coined "Black Control." He used discard effects early with cards like Ravenous Rats, Duress, and Stupor. However, the majority of his deck was dedicated to board control with Cursed Scrolls, Powder Kegs, and Phyrexian Plaguelords.
